Fun Fact: Xylocopa tabaniformis, also known as the horsefly-like carpenter bee, has a fuzzy abdomen that helps it collect pollen efficiently.
Name: Horse-fly Carpenter Bee

Fun Fact: California bumble bees are important pollinators of wildflowers and crops, including tomatoes, peppers, and cranberries.
Name: California Bumble Bee

Fun Fact: The Syrphid fly, Toxomerus marginatus, is a bee mimic whose larvae are voracious aphid predators, making them a gardener's best friend.
Name: Margined Calligrapher

Fun Fact: The Blue-eyed Darner dragonfly's bright blue eyes can see nearly 360 degrees!
Name: Blue-eyed Darner

Fun Fact: The Mitred parakeet is known for forming massive communal roosts, sometimes with hundreds or even thousands of individuals squawking together!
Name: Mitred Parakeet

Fun Fact: Pallid-winged grasshoppers can form massive swarms that travel hundreds of miles, devouring crops in their path!
Name: Pallid-winged Grasshopper

Fun Fact: The peregrine falcon is the fastest animal on Earth, reaching speeds of over 200 mph during its hunting dives!
Name: Peregrine Falcon

Fun Fact: The resplendent clearwing moth mimics the appearance of a wasp, deterring predators with its convincing disguise.
Name: Sycamore Borer Moth

Fun Fact: The three-lined potato beetle, *Lema daturaphila*, is a bit of a picky eater, preferring plants in the nightshade family, like potatoes, tomatoes, and even some weeds!
Name: Three-lined Potato Beetle

Fun Fact: Willow Flycatchers change their song depending on where they live, creating regional dialects!
Name: Willow Flycatcher

Fun Fact: Euphyllura olivina nymphs create protective, cotton-like shelters on olive trees, sometimes leading to them being called "olive psyllid cottony nymphs."

Fun Fact: The Western Pygmy Blue butterfly, Brephidium exilis, is one of the smallest butterflies in the world, with a wingspan about the size of your fingernail!
Name: Western Pygmy-Blue

Fun Fact: The quick-dispersing Zonitoides arboreus snail can spread rapidly thanks to its ability to reproduce asexually and its tendency to hitchhike on plants and animals.
Name: Quick Gloss Snail

Fun Fact: The twenty-spotted lady beetle, Psyllobora vigintimaculata, is a fungus-eating ladybug, unlike most of its relatives who prefer munching on aphids.
Name: Twenty-spotted Lady Beetle

Fun Fact: The beetle Cerobasis guestfalica can survive for over a year without food or water by entering a state of suspended animation.

Fun Fact: Neocoelidiana obscura, a leafhopper, has nymphs that can change their body color to match the color of the leaf they're feeding on for camouflage!

Fun Fact: The American Lady butterfly is a master of disguise, using its muted colors to blend in with bark and leaf litter.
Name: American Lady

Fun Fact: California voles are excellent swimmers and often use waterways to escape predators or travel to new areas.
Name: California Vole

Fun Fact: The western harvest mouse, *Reithrodontomys megalotis*, often builds its nest off the ground, weaving it into tall grasses or shrubs.

Fun Fact: Dione vanillae butterflies have a peculiar taste for passionflower vines, and caterpillars can store toxins from these plants, making them unpalatable to predators!

Fun Fact: The wrentit, *Chamaea fasciata*, is so unique it's the only species in its genus *Chamaea* and family Chamaeidae.
Name: Wrentit

Fun Fact: Black-headed Grosbeaks are sometimes called "cut-throats" because the male's song sounds like he's clearing his throat!
Name: Black-headed Grosbeak

Fun Fact: Silverfish can live for a year or more without eating!
Name: Long-tailed Silverfish

Fun Fact: Perdita rhois bees are so tiny that they can nest in the hollow stems of plants.
Name: Rhus Fairy Bee

Fun Fact: The checkered white butterfly, Pontia protodice, can have different wing patterns depending on the season, with summer forms often being more heavily marked than spring forms.
Name: Checkered White

Fun Fact: The eucalyptus snout beetle, Gonipterus platensis, can defoliate entire eucalyptus plantations, but their larvae carry a "backpack" of their own poop for protection.
Name: Eucalyptus snout beetle

Fun Fact: Silverfish can live for a year or more without eating.
Name: Four-lined Silverfish

Fun Fact: The Ozodiceromyia nigrimana fly is a master of disguise, mimicking wasps to avoid predation!
Name: Black Soldier Fly

Fun Fact: Toxomerus politus, also known as the Maize Calligrapher Fly, is a master of disguise, mimicking wasps to avoid predators!
Name: Maize Calligrapher

Fun Fact: Brachymyrmex patagonicus ants are so tiny they can nest inside acorns!
Name: Dark Rover Ant

Fun Fact: The fly, Minettia flaveola, is known to aggregate in large numbers on fresh dung, likely to feed and mate.
Name: Yellow dung fly

Fun Fact: Turkey vultures can smell carrion from up to a mile away!
Name: Turkey Vulture

Fun Fact: The cat-faced spider, *Araneus gemma*, can change its color to blend in with its surroundings, ranging from pale yellow to reddish-brown!
Name: Gem-shaped Orbweaver

Fun Fact: Prenolepis imparis ants can survive for months without food by slowing down their metabolism and feeding on their own fat reserves.
Name: American Winter Ant

Fun Fact: The western homoneurid fly, *Homoneura occidentalis*, sometimes gathers in large groups on foliage, possibly as a form of mate-finding behavior.
Name: Western Lauxaniid Fly

Fun Fact: Spotted cucumber beetles, also known as Diabrotica undecimpunctata, can transmit plant diseases while also enjoying a diet of over 200 different plant species!
Name: Spotted Cucumber Beetle

Fun Fact: Western drywood termites can live completely inside wood without ever needing to contact the soil.
Name: Western Drywood Termite

Fun Fact: The gall created by the Amphibolips quercuspomiformis wasp can look so much like an apple that it's sometimes called an "apple gall."
Name: Live Oak Apple Gall Wasp

Fun Fact: The Endeavouria septemlineata, a type of goby, can change its color to blend in with its surroundings, helping it avoid predators or ambush prey.
Name: Bumblebee

Fun Fact: The two-lined spittlebug, *Prosapia ignifera*, can jump over 70 times its body length, which is like a human jumping over a football field!
Name: Red-banded spittlebug

Fun Fact: Full grown weevils are all female and don't need males to reproduce.

Fun Fact: Rhopalomyia californica, also known as the coyote bush gall midge, creates distinctive, fuzzy galls on coyote bush plants that look like pom-poms.

Fun Fact: Nephus guttulatus beetles are like tiny, spotted superheroes of the citrus world, helping to control populations of citrus mealybugs and scale insects that can damage fruit trees!

Fun Fact: The leaf mines created by *Calycomyza malvae* larvae can look like tiny, meandering works of art on mallow leaves.

Fun Fact: The slug Milax gagates, also known as the jet black slug, can vary in color and may not always be black!
Name: Greenhouse Slug

Fun Fact: Antianthe expansa, a sea slug, has a symbiotic relationship with algae that live within its body, providing it with nutrients through photosynthesis!

Fun Fact: Acizzia hakeae creates protective, sugary lerps that look like tiny white scales on Hakea plants.
Name: Hakea psyllid

Fun Fact: The Eleodes littoralis beetle can survive being submerged in water for up to 45 minutes by trapping air bubbles under its elytra.
Name: Beach Tenebrionid

Fun Fact: Cassin's Kingbirds, also known as Tyrannus vociferans, can mimic the calls of other birds, likely to trick them into revealing their location!
Name: Cassin's Kingbird

Fun Fact: The cotton seed bug, *Oxycarenus hyalinipennis*, can cause significant economic damage to cotton crops by feeding on developing seeds and lint, sometimes leading to yield losses of up to 50%.
Name: Cotton Seed Bug

Fun Fact: Carpenter bees like Xylocopa tabaniformis orpifex create perfectly round entrance holes in wood, often leading to multiple nesting chambers!
Name: Foothill Carpenter Bee

Fun Fact: The Chestnut-sided Warbler can change its song based on its surroundings and whether it's trying to attract a mate or defend its territory.
Name: Chestnut-sided Warbler

Fun Fact: The iridescent, golden-green Diachus auratus beetle gets its shimmering color from microscopic structures on its wing covers that reflect light.
Name: Bronze Leaf Beetle

Fun Fact: Red-whiskered Bulbuls, *Pycnonotus jocosus*, can mimic the calls of other birds and even some mechanical sounds!
Name: Red-whiskered Bulbul

Fun Fact: The red admiral butterfly can taste with its feet!
Name: Red Admiral

Fun Fact: Glassy-winged sharpshooters can transmit a plant-killing bacteria called Xylella fastidiosa, earning them the nickname "plant vampires."
Name: Glassy-winged Sharpshooter

Fun Fact: Parakontikia ventrolineata, a colorful land planarian, can regenerate into two complete individuals if cut in half lengthwise.
Name: Hammerhead worm

Fun Fact: Castianeira thalia spiders are known for their speed and agility, often running sideways like crabs to evade predators.
Name: Ant spider

Fun Fact: Litargus balteatus beetles are known to be predators of mites and scale insects, making them beneficial insects in agricultural settings!
Name: Silken fungus beetle

Fun Fact: The dingy cutworm, *Feltia subterranea*, can cause significant damage to crops by feeding on plant stems at or below the soil surface, often severing them and leading to plant death.
Name: Subterranean Dart

Fun Fact: The pear-shaped scale insect, Protopulvinaria pyriformis, is a sap-sucking insect that, despite its small size, can cause significant damage to ornamental plants by weakening them and promoting the growth of sooty mold!
Name: Pyriform Scale

Fun Fact: This fern's name, *Pellaea stictica*, refers to the sticky substance it produces, likely as a defense mechanism against herbivores or to help retain moisture.
Name: Sticky cliff brake

Fun Fact: Rhopalomyia floccosa galls, formed on coyote brush, can look so much like flowers that they're often mistaken for them!
Name: Sagebrush Woolly Stem Gall Midge

Fun Fact: Paropsisterna m-fuscum larvae use their own fecal shields for protection from predators!
Name: Eucalyptus Leaf Beetle

Fun Fact: Cryptamorpha desjardinsi is known to inhabit the nests of social spiders, feeding on dead insects and spider droppings within the nest.
Name: Desjardins's Flat Beetle

Fun Fact: Gosodesmus claremontus millipedes are so tiny, they're smaller than a grain of rice!
Name: Pink Feather Boa Millipede

Fun Fact: Lauria cylindracea snails can survive being frozen for several weeks!
Name: Common Chrysalis-Snail

Fun Fact: Lasioglossum ovaliceps bees have a unique way of defending themselves by curling into a tight ball when threatened, resembling a tiny, fuzzy pill!
Name: Oval-headed Sweat Bee

Fun Fact: Brown-banded cockroaches prefer warm, humid environments and can often be found hiding in electronics like TVs and microwaves.
Name: Brown-banded Cockroach

Fun Fact: The painted wood turtle, Rhinoclemmys pulcherrima manni, boasts a unique "fingerprint" on its shell, as no two individuals share the exact same pattern of vibrant red and yellow markings!
Name: Central American Wood Turtle

Fun Fact: The Painted Wood Turtle, Rhinoclemmys pulcherrima, is known for its vibrant colors and patterns, which are unique to each individual turtle, like a fingerprint!
Name: Painted Wood Turtle

Fun Fact: Nanday parakeets are known for their loud, distinctive calls, often described as sounding like they're "arguing" or "scolding."
Name: Nanday Parakeet

Fun Fact: The Forficula dentata earwig exhibits maternal care, guarding its eggs and newly hatched nymphs, which is unusual for insects.
Name: Western Earwig

Fun Fact: The slime mold *Leocarpus fragilis* is also known as "insect eggs slime" due to its resemblance to a cluster of insect eggs.
Name: insect-egg slime

Fun Fact: Metaltella simoni spiders are known for their communal living, where dozens or even hundreds of individuals can cooperate in building and maintaining massive web complexes.
Name: South American Toothed Hacklemesh Weaver

Fun Fact: Harford's jumping spider has a unique courtship display where the male waves his first pair of legs and vibrates his abdomen to attract a female.
Name: Harford's jumping spider

Fun Fact: Nigma linsdalei, also known as the Linsdale's Meshweb Spider, is unique because it's one of the few spider species known to exhibit social behavior, living in communal webs with hundreds of individuals.
Name: Linsdale's Nurseryweb Spider

Fun Fact: Olive fruit flies can detect the color yellow, which is why yellow sticky traps are often used to monitor and control their populations in olive groves.
Name: Olive fruit fly

Fun Fact: The potato psyllid, Bactericera cockerelli, can transmit a bacterium that causes "zebra chip" disease in potatoes, making the potatoes look striped when fried.
Name: Potato Psyllid

Fun Fact: The Bactericera maculipennis, also known as the potato psyllid, can transmit a bacterium to potato plants that causes "zebra chip" disease, making the potatoes look striped and taste bitter when fried!
Name: Potato psyllid

Fun Fact: The Texas acacia psyllid, *Heteropsylla texana*, can cause significant leaf drop on acacia trees but usually doesn't kill the tree, making it more of a nuisance than a deadly pest.
Name: Mesquite Psyllid

Fun Fact: The Jumping Bristle-grass Psyllid's nymphs make little cone-shaped galls on grass blades, like tiny teepees for bugs!
Name: Syzygium Leaf Psyllid

Fun Fact: Three-striped cucumber beetles can transmit squash mosaic virus and other diseases to cucurbit crops.
Name: Western Striped Cucumber Beetle

Fun Fact: The Gratiana pallidula, also known as the eggplant tortoise beetle, is a master of disguise, using its own excrement to create a "shield" that deters predators.
Name: Eggplant Tortoise Beetle

Fun Fact: The longhorn beetle Apocrypha anthicoides mimics soldier beetles to avoid predators.
Name: Ant beetle

Fun Fact: Tetraleurodes perileuca nymphs create elaborate, waxy "snowflake" patterns on the undersides of leaves.
Name: Stanford's Whitefly

Fun Fact: Menemerus bivittatus, the gray wall jumper, can jump over 50 times their own body length!
Name: Gray Wall Jumping Spider

Fun Fact: Varied carpet beetle larvae are often mistaken for pantry pests because they feed on a wide range of items, including grains, spices, and pet food.
Name: Varied Carpet Beetle

Fun Fact: The Red-naped Sapsucker drills neat rows of sapwells in trees, creating "sap ladders" that attract insects and hummingbirds, benefiting the entire forest ecosystem.
Name: Red-naped Sapsucker

Fun Fact: Despite their name, the American cockroach is believed to have originated in Africa.
Name: Western Wood Cockroach

Fun Fact: The cabbage seedpod weevil, Ceutorhynchus obstrictus, can detect the scent of its host plants from over a kilometer away!
Name: Cabbage seed Weevil

Fun Fact: The Fieberiella florii can communicate with each other using vibrations they send through the plants they live on.
Name: Privet Leafhopper

Fun Fact: The Nomophila nearctica, or lucerne moth, can migrate hundreds of miles in a single flight, sometimes aided by jet streams!
Name: Lucerne Moth

Fun Fact: Costa's hummingbirds can survive on flower nectar and insects, but they have also been known to drink sap from holes drilled by sapsuckers!
Name: Costa's Hummingbird

Fun Fact: The diabolical ironclad beetle, Phloeodes diabolicus, can withstand being run over by a car because its exoskeleton can handle approximately 39,000 times its own body weight.
Name: Diabolical Ironclad Beetle

Fun Fact: The blue bottle fly, Calliphora vicina, is often one of the first insects to arrive at a dead body, making them valuable to forensic entomologists in estimating time of death!
Name: Blue Blowfly

Fun Fact: Aceria paracalifornica mites cause witches' brooms, dense clusters of distorted twigs, on their pine tree hosts.
Name: California Sagebrush Gall Mite

Fun Fact: Big-eared woodrats, also known as *Neotoma macrotis*, are skilled nest builders and often incorporate shiny objects they find into their homes, leading to the nickname "trade rat" due to their habit of swapping out items.
Name: Big-eared Woodrat

Fun Fact: The Smerinthus ophthalmica moth has striking eyespots on its hindwings that it flashes to startle predators.
Name: Western Eyed Sphinx

Fun Fact: German cockroaches can run up to 3 miles per hour, making them some of the fastest insects on Earth.
Name: German Cockroach

Fun Fact: Unlike most fruit flies that prefer rotting fruit, the female spotted wing drosophila can lay eggs in ripening fruit, causing significant damage to crops.
Name: Spotted-winged Drosophila

Fun Fact: In some cultures, the black witch moth is associated with death or bad luck, while in others, it symbolizes money or good fortune.
Name: Black Witch

Fun Fact: The caterpillar of the Manduca quinquemaculatus, also known as the tomato hornworm, can eat an entire tomato plant in a single day!
Name: Five-spotted Hawk Moth

Fun Fact: The Painted Tiger Moth (Arachnis picta) caterpillars have a unique defense mechanism: they regurgitate on predators when threatened!
Name: Painted Tiger Moth

Fun Fact: Toumeyella liriodendri, also known as the tuliptree scale, excretes a sugary substance called honeydew that attracts ants, bees, and wasps, which in turn protect the scale from predators!
Name: Tuliptree scale

Fun Fact: The Aloe mite, *Aceria aloinis*, causes bizarre, tumor-like growths called galls on aloe plants.
Name: Aloe Gall Mite

Fun Fact: The common green darner dragonfly, Anax junius, can migrate over 1,000 miles, sometimes traveling in swarms so large they appear on weather radar!
Name: Common Green Darner

Fun Fact: Habronattus pyrrithrix males have iridescent leg scales they flash during their elaborate courtship dances, which are visible in ultraviolet light.
Name: Regal jumping spider

Fun Fact: Allograpta exotica larvae are voracious aphid predators and can consume up to 400 aphids during their development!
Name: Exotic Streaktail

Fun Fact: The potter wasp Ancistrocerus tuberculocephalus meticulously crafts tiny mud pots as nests, often adorning them with whimsical, bumpy textures!
Name: Potter wasp

Fun Fact: Indian meal moths can chew through plastic and cardboard to get to your snacks!
Name: Indian-Meal Moth

Fun Fact: Danepteryx robusta males have incredibly long antennae, sometimes longer than their entire body length!
Name: Parsley

Fun Fact: The Liorhyssus hyalinus, also known as the hyaline grass bug, can sometimes be found overwintering in large groups, creating quite the buggy slumber party!
Name: Hyaline Grass Bug

Fun Fact: The Cuban laurel thrips, *Gynaikothrips ficorum*, induces distinctive and sometimes elaborate leaf galls on its host plants that look like tiny homes.
Name: Cuban Laurel Thrips

Fun Fact: Olla v-nigrum larvae are voracious aphid predators, consuming up to 50 aphids a day!
Name: Ashy Gray Lady Beetle

Fun Fact: The Campyloneura virgula is a plant bug known to feed on nettles, but it's also been observed sipping nectar from flowers!
Name: Leafhopper

Fun Fact: The dragonfly *Paltothemis lineatipes* can sometimes be seen resting or perching vertically, hanging from vegetation like a tiny, colorful ornament.
Name: Red Rock Skimmer

Fun Fact: Tarantula hawks like Pepsis thisbe are parasitoid wasps that deliver one of the most painful stings in the insect world, primarily to immobilize tarantulas for their larvae to feed on.
Name: Thisbe's Tarantula-hawk Wasp

Fun Fact: Triepeolus verbesinae, a cuckoo bee, sneaks into the nests of plasterer bees in the genus Colletes to lay its eggs, and its larvae then devour the host's pollen stores!
Name: Verbesina Longhorn-Cuckoo

Fun Fact: Rose aphids can reproduce asexually, allowing a single female to start a whole colony without needing a mate!
Name: Rose Aphid

Fun Fact: The slender soft-winged grass-carrying wasp, Isodontia elegans, stocks its nests with paralyzed grasshoppers and katydids for its young to eat, sometimes using so many that the nest appears overflowing!
Name: Elegant Grass-carrying Wasp

Fun Fact: The caterpillar of Scybalistodes periculosalis can roll itself up inside a leaf for protection.
Name: Asiatic garden borer

Fun Fact: The sharpshooter Graphocephala cythura can transmit bacteria that cause diseases in economically important plants.
Name: Blue-green sharpshooter

Fun Fact: Cyclocephala lurida beetles are attracted to the volatile compounds released by fermenting turfgrass and decaying organic matter, sometimes leading to large gatherings near compost piles or areas with poor drainage.
Name: Southern Masked Chafer

Fun Fact: The Anise Swallowtail butterfly, Papilio zelicaon, can taste with its feet!
Name: Anise Swallowtail

Fun Fact: Macrophthalmothrips argus has the largest known compound eyes relative to its head size of any known thrip species.
Name: Argus Onion Thrips

Fun Fact: The Chabulina onychinalis is so tiny that it's smaller than a grain of rice!
Name: Swan plant flower moth

Fun Fact: The autumnal belle moth, Cyclophora nanaria, has a wingspan of only about 2 cm, making it a tiny treasure to spot!
Name: Dwarf Tawny Wave

Fun Fact: The spotted snake millipede, *Blaniulus guttulatus*, can sometimes be found in large numbers causing damage to crops, particularly strawberries and potatoes.
Name: Spotted Snake Millipede

Fun Fact: Anthomyia oculifera, a type of fly, has iridescent eyes that change color depending on the angle of the light.
Name: Beach fly

Fun Fact: Longtailed mealybugs secrete honeydew, which ants love, so they'll protect the mealybugs from predators in exchange for the sweet treat!
Name: long-tailed mealybug

Fun Fact: The silver argiope spider's web shimmers with a zig-zag pattern of silk called a stabilimentum, which reflects UV light to attract unsuspecting insect prey.
Name: Silver Garden Orbweaver

Fun Fact: Diamond Doves form strong pair bonds and often preen each other as a sign of affection.
Name: Diamond Dove

Fun Fact: Water striders, like Limnoporus notabilis, can skate on water due to tiny hairs on their legs that repel water.
Name: Water strider

Fun Fact: Brachymelecta californica, a cleptoparasitic bee, sneaks into the nests of other bees to lay its eggs on their pollen provisions, essentially stealing their hard-earned food for its own offspring!
Name: California Digger-cuckoo Bee

Fun Fact: Leptoglossus zonatus, also known as the Western Leaf-footed bug, communicates with vibrations they send through plants.
Name: Leaf-footed bug

Fun Fact: The western red-tailed hawk, *Buteo jamaicensis calurus*, has highly variable plumage, with some individuals being so dark they appear almost black!
Name: Western Red-tailed Hawk

Fun Fact: The Pacific Forktail damselfly's blue coloration can actually change depending on its body temperature, becoming more purple in cooler conditions.
Name: Pacific Forktail

Fun Fact: Despite their tiny size, Varroa mites can transmit at least 18 different viruses to honeybees.
Name: Varroa Mite

Fun Fact: Pigeons can recognize all 26 letters of the English alphabet.
Name: Feral Pigeon

Fun Fact: Pigeons can recognize themselves in a mirror, a trait shared by only a few other species like humans, dolphins, and chimpanzees.
Name: Rock Pigeon

Fun Fact: Female Anthidiellum notatum bees use plant resin and pebbles to construct nests, creating tiny fortresses for their young.
Name: Northern Rotund-Resin Bee

Fun Fact: Cyclosa turbinata spiders decorate their webs with debris and dead insects, often arranged to resemble a larger spider, likely to deter predators.
Name: Humped Trashline Orbweaver

Fun Fact: Zaprionus tuberculatus, also known as the African fig fly, can be a serious pest because it's attracted to damaged fruit, unlike many other fruit flies that prefer perfectly ripe fruit.
Name: African fig fly

Fun Fact: Cowpea aphids can reproduce so quickly that a single aphid can produce up to 80 offspring in just one week!
Name: Cowpea Aphid

Fun Fact: The garden tortrix moth, Clepsis peritana, has a wide range of host plants, feeding on over 100 different species!
Name: Garden Tortrix

Fun Fact: Zootermopsis angusticollis, also known as the Pacific dampwood termite, can produce defensive secretions with a distinct garlic-like odor when threatened!
Name: Pacific Dampwood Termite

Fun Fact: The hawthorn lace bug, Corythucha confraterna, creates intricate, lace-like patterns on the leaves it feeds on, which can sometimes look like artwork.
Name: Western Sycamore Lace Bug

Fun Fact: The Pink-spotted hawkmoth, also known as Agrius cingulata, can hover in mid-air while feeding on nectar from flowers.
Name: Pink-spotted Hawkmoth

Fun Fact: Deroceras invadens can reproduce asexually, meaning a single slug can start an entire population all by itself!
Name: Chestnut Slug

Fun Fact: The Stigmella heteromelis moth is so tiny that its wingspan is only about the width of a human fingernail.
Name: ʻĀnunuu Leafminer

Fun Fact: The broad-headed sharpshooter, *Pagaronia tredecimpunctata*, can jump up to 50 times its own body length!
Name: Twospotted Graphocephala

Fun Fact: Barn swallows can drink while flying by skimming the water's surface with their lower mandible.
Name: Barn Swallow

Fun Fact: The hemispherical scale, Saissetia coffeae, is a prolific pest that can reproduce asexually, meaning a single female can start an entire infestation without needing a mate!
Name: Hemispherical Scale

Fun Fact: The American yellow sac spider, *Cheiracanthium inclusum*, doesn't spin a web to catch prey; instead, it actively hunts at night and hides in a silken sac during the day.
Name: Agrarian Sac Spider

Fun Fact: Halictus ligatus bees exhibit a fascinating social flexibility, where they can switch between solitary and social nesting behaviors depending on environmental conditions.
Name: Ligated Furrow Bee

Fun Fact: Ectopsocus vachoni, a species of barklouse, can reproduce parthenogenetically, meaning females can produce offspring without mating!
Name: Barklouse

Fun Fact: The Calephelis nemesis butterfly has a clever camouflage; its wing patterns mimic bird droppings to avoid predators!
Name: Fatal Metalmark

Fun Fact: The California Valley Coyote, Canis latrans ochropus, can run up to 40 mph and jump distances of almost 14 feet.
Name: California Valley Coyote

Fun Fact: Allacrotelsa spinulata is one of the few gecko species that is parthenogenetic, meaning it reproduces without needing a male.
Name: Silverfish

Fun Fact: Serratia marcescens is famous for sometimes producing a red pigment called prodigiosin, which in the past led people to believe that bread and communion wafers were "bleeding," causing widespread fear and religious awe!
Name: Serratia

Fun Fact: Hemieuxoa rudens, a microscopic animal living in marine sediments, can withstand extreme oxygen deprivation, surviving for weeks or even months without oxygen.
Name: Creaky Dart

Fun Fact: The caterpillar of Tachystola hemisema creates a mobile home by webbing together leaves and carrying it around for protection!
Name: Apple moth

Fun Fact: These beetles often bask in the sun to raise their body temperature, allowing them to fly more efficiently.
Name: Figeater

Fun Fact: Oegoconia novimundi caterpillars are known to feed on a wide range of decaying plant matter, including stored grains, making them a potential pest in agricultural settings!
Name: Four-spotted Yellowneck Moth

Fun Fact: The bifurcated fingernail clam, *Dishkeya bifurcata*, is so tiny you could fit several adults on a single fingernail!
Name: Sand dollar

Fun Fact: Devil's coach horse larvae use their mandibles to tear apart prey and then regurgitate digestive enzymes onto the remains, predigesting them before consuming the resulting soup.
Name: hairy rove beetle

Fun Fact: Liriomyza temperata, a leafminer fly, can cause significant damage to vegetable crops, but adult flies also feed on nectar, helping to pollinate plants in the process.
Name: Tomato leafminer

Fun Fact: The Green Stink Bug (Chinavia hilaris) releases a pungent odor when disturbed, deterring predators and even attracting other stink bugs to form aggregations.
Name: Green Stink Bug

Fun Fact: *Bourletiella juanitae* is a springtail that can jump up to 100 times its body length!
Name: Springtail

Fun Fact: Leptonemertes chalicophora is a ribbon worm that can be found living inside the gills of certain sea squirts.
Name: Lineus chalicophorus

Fun Fact: The Chinese wax scale insect produces a thick, waxy coating that was historically used to make candles and other products.
Name: Chinese Wax Scale

Fun Fact: Akamptogonus novarae is a millipede that curls into a spiral shape when threatened, resembling a tiny cinnamon roll!
Name: Millipede

Fun Fact: Josephiella microcarpae figs are pollinated by their own specific wasp species, which can only reproduce within these particular figs.
Name: Ficus Gall Wasp

Fun Fact: These beetles are often found enjoying a free meal in the company of ants!
Name: Pollen beetle

Fun Fact: The wavy-lined emerald moth camouflages itself by decorating its body with bits of flowers and leaves from the plants it eats!
Name: Wavy-lined Emerald

Fun Fact: Tamalia coweni aphids can manipulate their host plant to create galls that provide them with shelter and food.
Name: Manzanita Leafgall Aphid

Fun Fact: The longhorn beetle, Nathrius brevipennis, is a wood-boring insect that is able to fly even though it has very short wings!
Name: Longhorn Beetle

Fun Fact: The jumping spider *Phanias monticola* has iridescent scales that shimmer in the sunlight, potentially used for attracting mates or camouflage!
Name: Sierra Madre Spider

Fun Fact: Araneus andrewsi, also known as Andrews' orbweaver, is known to vary in color from pale yellow to bright orange, helping them to blend in with the flowers they often inhabit!
Name: Andrews' Cross Spider

Fun Fact: Scotophaeus blackwalli, also known as the mouse spider, can flatten their bodies to squeeze into incredibly tight spaces, like under floorboards or behind furniture!
Name: Mouse Spider

Fun Fact: Western black widow spider venom is 15 times more potent than rattlesnake venom, though they inject a much smaller dose.
Name: Western Black Widow

Fun Fact: Alopecosa kochi spiders, also known as wolf spiders, are skilled hunters that don't build webs; instead, they chase down their prey with surprising speed and agility.
Name: Koch's Wolf Spider

Fun Fact: Falconina gracilis is a tiny spider, with the males of some Falconina species being smaller than the females they prey upon before mating.
Name: Spider

Fun Fact: These common house spiders are excellent recyclers, happily consuming shed exoskeletons and dead insects.
Name: Common House Spider

Fun Fact: The larvae of Lucilia sericata, or the common green bottle fly, are used in maggot therapy to clean wounds, as they only consume dead tissue and secrete antibacterial compounds!
Name: Common European Greenbottle Fly

Fun Fact: Copestylum marginatum flies are sometimes called "garbage flies" because their larvae are often found in decaying organic matter!
Name: Margined Calligrapher

Fun Fact: The larvae of Galgula partita are known to feed on plants in the Amaranthaceae family, including some species of pigweed.
Name: Wedgling Moth

Fun Fact: The Tolype distincta caterpillar has urticating hairs that can cause skin irritation upon contact.
Name: Lappet Moth

Fun Fact: California Springtails are known for their ability to jump up to 100 times their body length!
Name: California twig ant

Fun Fact: American Pipits have a special protein in their blood that prevents their feet from freezing when they stand on ice and snow!
Name: American Pipit

Fun Fact: The nymphs of *Calophya californica* create distinctive lerps, or protective coverings, that look like tiny, white, cottony discs on the leaves of their host plants.
Name: lemonade berry psyllid

Fun Fact: Elipsocus hyalinus, a type of barklouse, can sometimes be found indoors, especially in places with high humidity, where they feed on mold and mildew.
Name: Common Barklouse

Fun Fact: The long-tailed psyllid, Ctenarytaina longicauda, produces honeydew that can attract ants, which then protect the psyllids from predators!
Name: Tristania Psyllid

Fun Fact: Wolf's milk slime mold, *Lycogala epidendrum*, may look like a tiny puffball, but it's actually a single-celled organism that can move and consume bacteria!
Name: Wolf's Milk

Fun Fact: Gibbobruchus mimus beetles can trick ants into carrying them back to the ant nest, where they then feast on ant larvae.
Name: Redbud Seed Weevil

Fun Fact: The Ozognathus cornutus, or horned armadillo, is known from a single, incomplete fossil skull, making much about its life a mystery!
Name: Giraffe weevil

Fun Fact: The White-faced Ibis, Plegadis chihi, often nests in colonies alongside other wading birds like herons and egrets, creating a bustling avian metropolis!
Name: White-faced Ibis

Fun Fact: The Rufous hummingbird, *Selasphorus rufus*, has the longest migration of any bird its size, traveling over 3,900 miles from Alaska and Canada to Mexico each year.
Name: Rufous, Allen's, and Allied Hummingbirds

Fun Fact: Crows can recognize human faces and hold grudges against people who have wronged them, even teaching other crows to dislike those individuals.
Name: Crows and Ravens

Fun Fact: Rose-breasted Grosbeaks use their strong bills to crack open seeds and even eat poisonous insects like monarch butterflies, without being harmed by the toxins!
Name: Rose-breasted Grosbeak

Fun Fact: Brown-headed cowbirds are brood parasites, meaning they lay their eggs in the nests of other bird species and leave the parenting to them!
Name: Brown-headed Cowbird

Fun Fact: The Swainson's thrush navigates its long migratory routes partly by using the Earth's magnetic field.
Name: Swainson's Thrush

Fun Fact: The Western Wood-Pewee often catches insects in mid-air with a distinctive, almost inaudible, snap of its bill.
Name: Western Wood-Pewee

Fun Fact: Plumbeous Vireos build cup-shaped nests so sturdy that Brown-headed Cowbirds, known for laying their eggs in other birds' nests, often avoid parasitizing them!
Name: Plumbeous Vireo

Fun Fact: Sapsuckers drill neat rows of holes in trees to drink the sap and also to attract insects, which they then eat!
Name: Sapsuckers

Fun Fact: The Red-breasted Sapsucker creates sapwells that attract insects, providing food for itself, hummingbirds, and other animals!
Name: Red-breasted Sapsucker

Fun Fact: Stinkpot turtles get their name from the musky odor they release when threatened.
Name: Eastern Musk Turtle

Fun Fact: Oecobius spiders are so small that they can squeeze through the eye of a needle!
Name: Wall Spiders

Fun Fact: Melissodes bees are specialized pollen collectors, often preferring the pollen of plants in the sunflower family.
Name: Long-horned bee

Fun Fact: The Whitebanded Crab Spider, *Misumenoides formosipes*, can change its color over a period of days to match the flower it's hunting on, providing excellent camouflage.
Name: White-banded Crab Spider

Fun Fact: American bullfrogs can jump up to ten times their body length.
Name: American Bullfrog

Fun Fact: *Monomorium ergatogyna* ants are unusual because the queen can be replaced by a worker ant if she dies, ensuring the colony's survival!
Name: Ergatogyne Trailing Ant

Fun Fact: The Western Pond Turtle can hold its breath for up to an hour!
Name: Western Pond Turtle

Fun Fact: Pristoceuthophilus, also known as cave crickets, use their long antennae to navigate in complete darkness and can jump surprisingly high when startled!
Name: Camel cricket

Fun Fact: Potter wasps are skilled architects, building intricate mud nests that resemble tiny pots or vases.
Name: Potter and Mason Wasps

Fun Fact: Some species of Chrysotoxum flies mimic wasps, not just in appearance, but also in their buzzing sounds, to deter predators.
Name: Meadow Flies

Fun Fact: Syrphid fly larvae in the Syrphini tribe are voracious aphid predators, making them a gardener's best friend!
Name: Flower fly

Fun Fact: The caterpillar of the Megalographa biloba moth mimics bird droppings to avoid predators.
Name: Bilobed Looper Moth

Fun Fact: Potter wasps, like *Ancistrocerus*, are solitary wasps that build tiny, vase-shaped nests out of mud, often provisioning them with paralyzed caterpillars as food for their larvae.
Name: Potter wasp

Fun Fact: Hylaeus bees, also known as masked bees, don't carry pollen on their legs or bodies like other bees; instead, they swallow it and regurgitate it at the nest!
Name: Masked Bees

Fun Fact: Mecaphesa spiders can jump over 50 times their own body length!
Name: Crab spider

Fun Fact: Yellow-rumped Warblers can digest waxes found in bayberries and wax myrtles, allowing them to survive further north than other warblers during the winter.
Name: Myrtle Warbler

Fun Fact: The Thaumatomyia glabra fly larva is a predator that feeds on root aphids living inside sugar beet plants.
Name: Grave fly

Fun Fact: The MacGillivray's Warbler, *Geothlypis tolmiei*, often hides its nest so well that it's nearly impossible for predators or birdwatchers to find!
Name: MacGillivray's Warbler

Fun Fact: Yellow Warblers sing different songs depending on whether they're trying to attract a mate or defending their territory.
Name: Yellow Warbler

Fun Fact: Reticularia lycoperdon, also known as the false puffball, sometimes appears as if someone dropped a handful of scrambled eggs on a log!
Name: False Puffball

Fun Fact: Potato leafhoppers secrete a toxin that disrupts plant growth, causing a characteristic "hopperburn" symptom on leaves.
Name: Potato Leafhopper

Fun Fact: Male Centris rhodopus bees have elongated hind legs that they use to grasp female bees during mating.
Name: Red-legged Oil-Digger

Fun Fact: The larvae of Ephestiodes gilvescentella are known to infest dried herbs and spices, sometimes even creating a "mat" of webbing in containers.
Name: Dusky Raisin Moth

Fun Fact: Stethorus punctum picipes is a tiny beetle, smaller than a pinhead, but it can devour up to 50 spider mites a day!
Name: Spider mite destroyer

Fun Fact: The Dipalta serpentina, or serpent fly, has larvae that are aquatic predators, using their elongated necks to strike at unsuspecting prey!
Name: Serpentine

Fun Fact: Castianeira athena spiders are known for their distinctive reddish-brown coloration and swift movements, often resembling ants, which helps them evade predators.
Name: Ant spider

Fun Fact: Rhyzobius lophanthae beetles are tiny predators that love to eat scale insects and are often used as a natural form of pest control in gardens and orchards!
Name: Purple Scale Predator

Fun Fact: The kidney-spot ladybird, Psyllobora renifer, exclusively eats mildew, a type of fungus, unlike most ladybugs that feast on aphids.
Name: Kidney-spotted Fairy Lady Beetle

Fun Fact: Cotton aphids can reproduce asexually, allowing them to rapidly build large populations.
Name: Melon Aphid

Fun Fact: Rhinacloa forticornis, a tiny plant bug, is known to feast on spider mites, making it a valuable natural pest control agent in agriculture!
Name: Western Plant Bug

Fun Fact: The cotton lace bug, Corythucha gossypii, can cause significant damage to cotton crops, but they also feed on other plants like soybeans, okra, and even weeds, making them a generalist pest!
Name: Cotton lace bug

Fun Fact: Red-eyed vireos are champion singers, sometimes singing over 20,000 songs in a single day!
Name: Red-eyed Vireo

Fun Fact: Gerrhosaurids, also known as plated lizards, can detach their tail as a defense mechanism, and some species can even regrow them!
Name: Gherkin

Fun Fact: Virginia's Warblers often nest in areas recovering from wildfires, using the burned trees and shrubs for cover.
Name: Virginia's Warbler

Fun Fact: The Tennessee Warbler undertakes one of the longest migrations of any warbler, traveling from Canada and Alaska to spend the winter in Central and South America.
Name: Tennessee Warbler

Fun Fact: Copestylum violaceum flies, also known as the violet carrion flies, are attracted to the smell of decaying organic matter but are also important pollinators of certain flowers.
Name: Violet dung fly

Fun Fact: The Zabul skipper, Burnsius albezens, can survive for months as a caterpillar by entering a state of dormancy called diapause.
Name: White Checkered-Skipper

Fun Fact: The Parancistrocerus declivatus wasp uses mud to build its nests in pre-existing cavities, sometimes even old beetle burrows in wood.
Name: Keyhole wasp

Fun Fact: Stethorus punctum beetles, also known as spider mite destroyers, can consume up to 60 spider mites per day!
Name: Spider Mite Destroyer

Fun Fact: The aquatic larvae of Thienemannimyia barberi can survive being frozen solid in ice!
Name: Barberi midge

Fun Fact: Halictus farinosus females sometimes cooperate in nest building and brood rearing, a behavior more commonly associated with social bees.
Name: Wide-striped Sweat Bee

Fun Fact: Acizzia uncatoides, also known as the acacia psyllid, can cause significant damage to acacia trees, but their honeydew production is a food source for ants and other insects, playing a role in the forest ecosystem.
Name: Acacia Psyllid

Fun Fact: Surinam cockroaches are all female and reproduce through parthenogenesis, meaning they don't need males to produce offspring!
Name: Surinam Cockroach

Fun Fact: The barnacle scale insect, *Ceroplastes cirripediformis*, gets its name from its waxy covering, which resembles a tiny, waxy barnacle and helps protect it from predators and environmental hazards.
Name: Barnacle Scale

Fun Fact: A goldfish's memory span is much longer than commonly believed; they can remember things for months, not just seconds!
Name: Goldfish

Fun Fact: Aceria baccharices are so tiny, they create structures called galls on Baccharis plants that look like colorful, alien worlds.
Name: Mule Fat Blister Mite

Fun Fact: California trapdoor spiders can live for over 20 years, patiently waiting in their burrows to ambush unsuspecting prey.
Name: California Trapdoor Spider

Fun Fact: Sophonia orientalis, a type of leafhopper, can jump over 100 times its own body length!
Name: Two-spotted Leafhopper

Fun Fact: Physella acuta, also known as the acute bladder snail, can reproduce asexually, meaning a single snail can start a whole new population!
Name: Acute Bladder Snail

Fun Fact: The cochineal scale insect, Dactylopius confusus, produces a vibrant red dye called carminic acid, which is used to color everything from food and cosmetics to textiles.
Name: American cochineal bug

Fun Fact: Pied-billed grebes can adjust their buoyancy by squeezing air from their feathers, allowing them to sink slowly or even disappear below the water's surface.
Name: Pied-billed Grebe

Fun Fact: Cycloneda polita larvae are voracious aphid predators, consuming up to 50 aphids per day.
Name: Western Polished Lady Beetle
